docs.lead_paragraph: The House early this morning passed a bill that would give doctors an exemption from antitrust laws so they could bargain collectively with insurance companies over fees and other issues. The vote was 276 to 136.
docs.abstract: House passes bill that would give doctors exemption from antitrust laws so they can bargain collectively with insurance companies over fees and other issues (M)
docs.snippet: The House early this morning passed a bill that would give doctors an exemption from antitrust laws so they could bargain collectively with insurance companies over fees and other issues.    The vote was 276 to 136.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 House Approves Money For Colombia Drug War The House approved an $11.2 billion spending bill that included emergency aid to battle drug traffickers and their rebel allies in Colombia, finance peacekeeping in Kosovo and provide disaster relief to flood and fire victims in the United States. A1 Compromise on Tribunal The United States won an agreement to keep the door open to further talks on its demand that no American official or soldier be surrendered to the permanent court for war crimes as long as Washington has not signed the treaty creating the court. A6 No Haste on Mideast Summit Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, in Jerusalem for meetings with Israeli and Palestinian leaders, said the Clinton administration did not feel pressured to call a summit meeting immediately. A6 Kohl Remains Defiant The former Chancellor of Germany, Helmut Kohl, appeared before a parliamentary committee investigating financial misdeeds under his rule, and he said he was a victim of slander. His stance was consistent with the defiance he has shown since his admission that he took about $1 million in undeclared payments from donors and used the money to bolster the Christian Democratic Party. A3 Refugees Feared Drowned An overloaded Indonesian ferry appeared to have sunk in heavy seas on route from Halmahera Island, and officials said they feared the loss of nearly 500 people, many of whom were fleeing religion-based killings in the remote Maluku Islands. A3 Vote in Uganda Ugandans voted in an unusual referendum on how they want to be governed, a question tied deeply to the violence of the nation's past and the popularity of President Yoweri Museveni, who in large measure has ended that violence. A6 World Briefing A9 NATIONAL A12-23 Abortion Foes Begin Work Drafting New Legislation A day after the Supreme Court struck down a law barring a procedure called by opponents partial-birth abortion, supporters of such bans said they were planning a new spate of laws they hoped would withstand further legal challenges. A1 Opening Books of Groups The Senate followed the House in approving a bipartisan bill to require tax-exempt groups that raise and spend money on political causes to disclose donors and expenditures. The president will sign it. A1 Some Elderly to Lose Coverage H.M.O.'s will cancel insurance coverage for more than 700,000 Medicare beneficiaries next year because the H.M.O.'s are cutting back their participation in Medicare, an industry trade group announced. A23 G.O.P. Patient Rights Bill The Senate voted, 51 to 47 largely on party lines, for limited patient protections, including a restricted right to sue H.M.O.'s, in legislation backed by the Republican majority. A23 Cuban Exile Lobby Not Yielding The Cuban American National Foundation began reorganizing its leadership and pledged to spend ''whatever it takes'' to preserve hard-line United States policies toward Cuba. A12 Commerce Secretary Nominee President Clinton nominated a former Democratic Congressman from California, Norman Y. Mineta, for secretary of commerce. Mr. Mineta would be the first Asian-American to hold a Cabinet post. A15 Fire at Nuclear Complex A fire ignited by a traffic accident swept the sagebrush at the Hanford nuclear complex in Washington State, burning across three radioactive waste sites. But officials said they had detected no release of radiation. A14 Decision on Alaska Airlines The F.A.A. accepted Alaska Airlines' remedial plan and will not shut down its maintenance operation, even though the agency found that the airline had allowed mechanics to perform work for which they were not qualified, skipped maintenance on test equipment and failed to tell pilots about inoperable equipment. A15 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Copy of 'Declaration' Fetches $7.4 Million Online A copy of the Declaration of Independence printed in 1776 and found behind a $4 flea-market painting in 1989 was sold over the Internet by Sotheby's for $7.4 million. B1 Why Reactor Wasn't Upgraded Con Edison decided in 1997 not to replace the steam generator that later caused an accident at the Indian Point 2 nuclear reactor, in Westchester County, because of uncertainty over the financial effects in the deregulated market that was developing, an internal document says. B1 Judge Cites Restaurant Union A federal judge cited New York's largest union of restaurant workers for contempt of court, finding it had defamed the Metropolitan Opera and improperly harassed board members as part of an effort to unionize 95 restaurant workers at the Met. B3 SCIENCE/HEALTH Drug Takes Weight Off Mice An experimental cancer drug, C75, made lab mice lose large amounts of weight without side effects. A18 WEEKEND E1-32; E33-52 SPORTS D1-8 Cleveland Slugger to Yanks The Yankees sent outfielder Ricky Ledee and two minor league players to be named to the Indians for outfielder David Justice. D1 Rocker in New York Heavy security surrounded John Rocker's presence in Manhattan and journey to Shea Stadium, by police van, not the No. 7 subway line. D1 Suspensions Are Lifted Baseball's chief operating officer overturned 12 of the suspensions imposed against 19 Los Angeles Dodgers for brawling with Cubs fans. D2 Pierce Gone From Wimbledon The French Open champion Mary Pierce lost to the 49th-ranked Magui Serna, 7-6 (5), 7-6 (4). D1 BUSINESS DAY C1-18 New Leader for Conseco Gary C. Wendt, who built GE Capital Services into a financial services powerhouse, was named chairman and chief executive of Conseco. The beleaguered insurance giant has been struggling the last two years, partly because of its costly acquisition of Green Tree Financial, which finances mobile-home purchases. C1 Effort to Trim Drug Spending Rx Health Value, a coalition of 69 health plans, several large employers, unions and consumer advocates, is beginning a campaign to slow spending on prescription drugs fueled by pharmaceutical marketing and advertising campaigns aimed at doctors and consumers. C1 Business Digest C1 OBITUARIES C18-19 Vittorio Gassman The versatile film star, who was also one of Italy's leading classical stage actors, was 77. C19 Charles A. MacGillivary A former Army sergeant awarded the Medal of Honor for a one-man foray against German machine-gun positions during the Battle of the Bulge, he was 83. C18 EDITORIAL A24-25 Editorials: Mr. Nader's misguided crusade; watching Mexico's election; privatization and failing schools; the AIDS epidemic in Africa. Columns: Gail Collins. Crossword E45 TV Listings E31 Public Lives B2 Weather B7

docs.lead_paragraph: A politically potent coalition of 69 health plans, several large employers, unions and consumer advocates is beginning a broad campaign to slow the surge in spending on prescription drugs. They hope to counter drugmakers' huge marketing and advertising campaigns directed at doctors and consumers. The coalition, Rx Health Value, includes Blue Cross and Blue Shield, Kaiser Permanente and 21 other independent nonprofit managed care companies. Together, they have 83 million members. Other members include General Motors; GTE; U S West; the pharmacy benefits manager PCS Health Systems; several employer-sponsored health care associations; the A.F.L.-C.I.O.; the United Automobile Workers; American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees; American Hospital Foundation; and AARP.
docs.abstract: Politically potent coalition of 69 health plans, several large employers, unions and consumer advocates called Rx Health Value is beginning broad campaign to slow surge in spending on prescription drugs; they hope to counter drugmakers' huge marketing and advertising campaigns directed at doctors and consumers; group plans to tell doctors and consumers about independent studies showing which drugs, old and new, are most effective, and will seek to increase influence of consumers in Washington; pharmaceutical companies spent $13.9 billion to market drugs in 1999, including pitches to doctors and advertising aimed at consumers; figure is 50 percent more than they spent in 1996, before regulators opened way to torrent of advertising directed at consumers; researchers at Brandeis University say in study sponsored by Rx Value Health that prescription drug costs of insured individuals rose 29 percent annually between 1996 and 1999; graph; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Cuban Rallies to Continue Elian Gonzalez is back, but Cuba's government plans to keep up public rallies in hope of rekindling a fading revolutionary ardor. PAGE A9

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK MANHATTAN: HUNGER STRIKE ENDS -- Eight janitors at a Brooklyn office tower ended a three-day hunger strike late Wednesday after City Councilman Guillermo Linares introduced a resolution that would bar city subsidies or tax breaks to building owners who violate the rights of workers. The hunger strikers were among 30 janitors at Brooklyn Renaissance Plaza who went on strike May 16 because the building's owner, Muss Development, refused to allow them to join the Service Employees International Union. Muss officials have denied any wrongdoing. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)
docs.abstract: Eight janitors at Brooklyn Renaissance Plaza end three-day hunger strike after Councilman Guillermo Linares introduces resolution that would bar city subsidies or tax breaks to building owners who violate workers' rights; workers charge Muss Development refused to allow them to join Service Employees International Union (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Health maintenance organizations will cancel insurance coverage for more than 700,000 Medicare beneficiaries next year because the H.M.O.'s are cutting back their participation in Medicare, an industry trade group announced today. Karen M. Ignagni, president of the trade group, the American Association of Health Plans, said the H.M.O.'s were pulling out of numerous counties because they had been ''over-regulated and underpaid'' by the federal government. Medicare payments to H.M.O.'s vary from county to county, depending in part on what Medicare spends for patients in its fee-for-service program.

headline.main: H.M.O.'s to Cancel Coverage Of 700,000 Getting Medicare

docs.abstract: American Assn of Health Plans, industry trade group, announces that health maintenance organizations will cancel insurance coverage for more than 700,000 Medicare beneficiaries next year because the HMO's are cutting back their participation in Medicare (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate voted tonight for limited patient protections supported by the Republican majority, including a restricted right to sue health maintenance organizations. The vote was 51 to 47, largely along party lines, and capped two weeks of intense partisanship in both the House and Senate over health care, which is expected to be a major issue in the fall campaign.

headline.main: In Senate, G.O.P. Back Bill of Rights For Patients

docs.abstract: Senate passes legislation for limited patient protections supported by Republican majority, including restricted right to sue health maintenance organizations (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: On the 19th floor of an office tower just two doors down from the New York Stock Exchange, brokers at a sprawling telephone dispatch center field a steady stream of calls from jittery clients, handling the requests in 18 different languages. The conversations have nothing to do with the ups and downs of the financial market next door. Instead, staff members at this Broad Street dispatch center -- speaking in English, Spanish, Haitian Creole, Urdu, Russian and Chinese, among other tongues -- are at the forefront of a revolution under way in New York City that, at least in theory, is fundamentally changing the way health care is delivered to the poor.

headline.main: Company Enrolling Poor in Health Care Plans Is Criticized

docs.abstract: Maximus Inc comes under criticism for its work in telephoning Medicaid recipients to get them to enroll in health insurance plans; Virginia-based company has $24-million contract to help poor New York City residents select family doctors and one of 18 health insurance programs, rather than relying on emergency rooms for basic medical care; company and state officials defend record of getting voluntary enrollments; photo of office where enrollment brokers handle calls in 18 languages (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The House passed a bill tonight offering prescription drug benefits to 39 million elderly and disabled people on Medicare, but only after a day of pitched battle, in which frustrated Democrats walked off the House floor at one point. The bill was passed by a vote of 217 to 214, with 5 Democrats voting for the measure and 10 Republicans voting against it. But the bill, which would expand Medicare more than any other measure passed in the 35-year history of the program by offering coverage for drug costs to all beneficiaries, now goes to the Senate, where its fate is uncertain.

headline.main: House Approves a Medicare Prescription Benefit

docs.abstract: House, 217-214, approves bill to offer prescription drug benefits to all 39 million elderly and disabled Medicare beneficiaries by subsidizing insurance companies that offer such coverage; Democratic minority, scoring Republican bill as sham and risky scheme that would 'privatize' Medicare, use variety of parliamentary and procedural tactics to delay work of House; score Republicans for blocking full debate on their bill for more extensive drug coverage; Pres Clinton, scoring Republican bill as empty promise, threatens veto (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's news conference yesterday at the White House, as recorded by The New York Times: Prepared Remarks With less than 35 days left in the legislative year, time is running out for Congress to meet its obligations to the American people. They have to make the tough choices to get something done or continue to be dragged down by the weight of special interests.
